title: High-Frame-Rate Optical Flow System
publicationTitle: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: In this paper, we develop a high-frame-rate (HFR) vision system that can estimate the optical flow in real time at 1000 f/s for 1024×1024 pixel images via the hardware implementation of an improved optical flow detection algorithm on a high-speed vision platform. Based on the Lucas-Kanade method, we adopt an improved gradient-based algorithm that can adaptively select a pseudo-variable frame rate according to the amplitude of the estimated optical flow to accurately detect the optical flow for objects moving at high and low speeds in the same image. The performance of our developed HFR optical flow system was verified through experimental results for high-speed movements such as a top's spinnning motion and a human's pitching motion.

authors.name: Idaku Ishii
authors.affiliation: Department of System Cybernetics, Hiroshima University, Hiroshima, Japan

p: Idaku Ishii (M'06) received the B.E., M.E., and Ph.D. degrees in mathematical engineering and information physics from the University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, in 1992, 1994, and 2000, respectively.

Currently, he is a Professor with Hiroshima University, Hiroshima, Japan. He was an Assistant Professor with the University of Tokyo from 1996 to 2000. In 2000, he joined the Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo, as a Lecturer, and was an Associate Professor from 2002 to 2003. He was an Associate Professor with Hiroshima University from 2003 to 2007. His current research interests include high-speed robot vision, sensory information processing, and its applications.

authors.name: Takeshi Takaki
authors.affiliation: Department of System Cybernetics, Hiroshima University, Hiroshima, Japan

p: Takeshi Takaki (M'03) received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in mechanical engineering from the Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan, in 2000 and 2002, respectively, and the Ph.D. degree in mechano-micro engineering from the Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, in 2006.

Currently, he is an Associate Professor with Hiroshima University, Hiroshima, Japan. From 2002 to 2003, he was with Disco Corporation, Tokyo. From 2006 to 2007, he was a Researcher with the Tokyo Institute of Technology. From 2007 to 2011, he was an Assistant Professor with Hiroshima University. His current research interests include mechanical design, robot hands, and sensory information processing.
